item.description:
I just stumbled upon the Coastal Trails Coalition, and would like to check out a couple of these rail trails in Salisbury.  I'm not familiar with any of them, so I can't guarantee anything, but what I've read sounds like they are both beautiful, with wooded and marsh views, and well-marked, flat, easy to navigate terrain.  See the info below to learn more about these trails! 

My plan is to start at the Old Eastern Marsh Trail, walk the 2.6 miles roundtrip, and then drive over to the Salisbury Point Ghost Trailhead and walk 3.4 miles round trip on that.  After our walk, let's grab lunch and drinks at The Winners Circle, or somewhere else nearby.  If the weather does not cooperate, I will cancel by 8 AM Sunday morning.

Parking and where to meet: The trailhead for Old Eastern Marsh is on Friedenfels Street, across from Striper's Restaurant on Route 1.  Parking is to the right of the granite railroad bridge.  After that trail, we'll drive the couple miles to Lions Park to pickup the East end of the Ghost trail (the west end is likely to be flooded from rains/springtime, so we'll start on the end that may not be flooded).  I will be bringing my dog, so other friendly pooches on leash (please bring bags) are welcomed along too.  This is cross-posted with Social Fun and Northshore Not Too Intense Hikers.

Old Eastern Marsh Trail:  1.3 mile paved trail from Friedenfels St. and the Merrimack River to Mudnock Road.  Beautiful walk through woods to an open expanse of the Great Marsh near Town Creek.  Outstanding birdwatching all year, animal tracking in winter, turtle nesting in spring.  Interpretive signs cover railroad history, history of the bridges and ferries crossing the Merrimack, Salisbury’s first settlers and Great Marsh Wildlife.

Salisbury Point Ghost Trail: 1.7 mile gravel trail from Lion’s Park in Salisbury Square to Rabbit Road with crossings at Cushing St. and Bartlett St.  Quiet walk through woodlands.  Interpretive signs at Bartlett St. give the story of the Ghost Trains and of New England’s biggest train robbery that took place right there.  Caution:  Parts of trail may be flooded in spring and after heavy rains
item.why: I do not have plans for this Easter weekend- anyone else free to do some exploring of these trails?
